entry.title: Re: Intra company subcontracting process
entry.content:
Hello @sopya1 

In S/4HANA Public Cloud, intra-company subcontracting between two plants is not a standard MM-subcontracting pattern.

For transfers occurring within the same company code, it is recommended to utilise the appropriate Stock Transfer scope items: BME – Stock Transfer with Delivery or BMH – Stock Transfer without Delivery. Please note that these options do not involve a vendor or the issuance of an invoice.SAP Learning-Exploring the Stock Transfer With Delivery (BME) Scenario

Subcontracting (BMY) is only for external suppliers and is managed with the Subcontracting Cockpit (F2948)—don’t model one plant as the subcontractor.

SAP Learning-Carrying out the Subcontracting Solution Process

For transactions involving charges between legal entities, structure them as intercompany arrangements (e.g., 5HP Advanced Intercompany Stock Transfer) instead of intra-company ones.SAP Help Portal-Setting Up Advanced Intercompany Stock Transfer

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Open Vendor Items Migration
Re: Problems with migration object Product - extend exist...
entry.content:
Hi @ornecogli 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at

Enhanced Migration Object: Product - extend existing record by new org levels

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/3c916ef10fc240c9afc594b346ffaf77/7a2ad47f16d54850b2a88befaf6e6eaa.html?locale=en-US for details.

Based on your screenshots, that error happens because multiple rows in your migration file refer to the same product number even if they are for different plants. The migration cockpit only allows you to use one update per product and per migration run. This is done to prevent conflicting updates.

Try splitting your file by product or plant, keep one file but run filtered migrations per plant. For large updates use API_PRODUCT_SRV to extend your plant data.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Open Vendor Items Migration
entry.content:
Hello @Jessicaaguilar1 

Thank you for your question and reaching out.

 

 

The “Supplier Open Items” migration template only supports FI-AP balances and open items; PO-referenced invoices and down payments are not included.

Supplier Open Items migration template FI – Accounts Payable Open Item doesn't support down payments, Special G/L “A” or down-payment requests. SAP KBA 2934405 states these are out of scope. SAP Support Portal-2934405 - Migration Cockpit - FI - Accounts payable open item does not allow Special G/L Indicator

This FI template is not connected to POs and does not support a PO-reference field. For PO documents, use S/4 instead of the AP open-items template. Addresses migration object scope and FI open-item restrictions. SAP Support Portal-3544356 - Out of Scope functionality in migration object 'FI - Accounts payable open item

Alternative options:

Migrate open POs using the “Purchase order (only open PO)” object; it loads POs that have not yet been delivered or invoiced. SAP Help Portal-Data Migration-MM - Purchase order (only open PO)

Then upload the supplier invoices with the PO reference directly to the S/4 HANA Public Cloud

Fiori app Create/Manage Supplier Invoice supports “with PO reference”. SAP Help Portal-Manage Supplier Invoices

Or via API API_SUPPLIERINVOICE_PROCESS_SRV “Create supplier invoice with PO reference” – HTTP POST. SAP Help Portal-APIs for Sourcing and Procurement-Create Supplier Invoice with Purchase Order

PO-based down payments: set DP data on the PO and process in S/4; monitor with Monitor Purchase Order Down Payments. (Not migratable via AP open-items template.) SAP Learning-Creating Purchase Orders with Down Payments

In summary, PO-referenced invoices or down payments cannot be loaded using the Supplier Open Items template. Instead, open-PO migration should be used, followed by posting invoices through the app or API, and managing PO down payments within S/4 Public Cloud.

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Questions on EBS SAP Public cloud
entry.content:
Hello @NagalakshmiGannavarapu 

Thanks for the screenshots. Here’s the exact, tenant-safe answer for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition:

Using ZR instead of SA

In Public Cloud, bank-statement posting rules are pre-delivered and unchangeable, so custom document types (ZR) can not be forced. G/L postings by EBS use standard types (e.g., SA), and sub-ledger clearings use the delivered AR/AP types. 

SAP Support Portal-3374309 - Posting and processing rules in bank statement posting - SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

Main bank not clearing; additional GL↔GL entry on the clearing account.

The example shows one document with Cr main bank / Dr clearing and another recording clearing ↔ clearing, leaving the bank line uncleared. This often results from incorrect posting rules or directions for the bank code and/or G/L→G/L setting instead of "clear customer/vendor/G/L open item.' Review the following steps:

  1. Global EBS settings

Account symbols and assignments: BANK_MAIN maps to main bank G/L; BANK_CLEAR maps to bank clearing G/L. SAP Help Portal-Configuring Bank Statement Processing

  1. Posting rule used for this transaction

Next, verify if the bank statement variant and account determination are correctly configured. Ensure the clearing account allows automatic clearing and no manual intervention is needed. If issues persist, check the mapping of external transaction codes to posting rules, as mismatches can cause uncleared bank lines or unexpected G/L movements. SAP Support Portal-2854415 - Information on Bank Statement Posting Rules in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition system

  1. Assign the bank’s external transaction code and sign to the applicable rule

In Assign External Transactions to Posting Rules, ensure the bank code and debit/credit sign point to the incoming rule; using an outgoing rule will flip the entry and prevent clearing. SAP Help Portal-Configuring Bank Statement Processing

  1. Make matching automatic

In Reprocess Bank Statement Items, apply processing rules and built-in interpretation algorithms to identify and clear open items, such as parsing reference or EndToEndId into the assignment. SAP Help Portal - Difference Between FEB_BSPROC and the Reprocess Bank Statement Items App

Recommended flow to verify the fix.

  • Verify that the main bank is Dr for incoming, that the clearing nets are zero in Area 1 and Area 2, and that the invoice/open item is cleared.

Let me know if it works

With best regards

Chuma

entry.title: Customer & Vendor Integration (CVI)
entry.content:
Table of Contents

  1. Introduction: The Big Change - What is CVI?
    • Purpose and Scope of This Guide
    • Why CVI is Mandatory in SAP S/4HANA
    • Goodbye Old Friends: The Limitations of Classic Customer/Vendor Master
  2. Meet the Business Partner (BP): Your New Single Source of Truth
    • The Power of the Business Partner: Key Advantages
    • Understanding BP Categories: Organization, Person, Group
    • The Role Concept: One Partner, Many Hats (Customer, Vendor, etc.)
  3. Business & Solution Impact: What This Means for You
    • Fiori App: Manage Customer Master Data
    • Fiori App: Manage Supplier Master Data
    • A New Way of Working: The BP Transaction and Fiori Apps
    • Obsolete vs. Redirected Transactions: A Clear Guide
    • Master Data Quality: The #1 Prerequisite
    • Navigating the New User Interface with Fiori
    • Understanding Authorizations in the BP World
  4. CVI Implementation Scenarios Explained
    • Greenfield (New Implementation): Starting Fresh
    • Brownfield (System Conversion): Migrating Your Existing System
  5. The System Conversion (Brownfield) Journey: A Step-by-Step Guide
    • The CVI Cockpit: Your Central Command Center
    • Master Data Cleansing: The Master Data Consistency Check
    • Automated Customizing Checks
    • Archiving Data Marked for Deletion
    • Critical Customizing for CVI Synchronization
      • Master Data Synchronization Setup
      • Number Ranges & Groupings: A Deep Dive with Examples
      • Value Mapping for Customers & Contact Persons
    • Using the Synchronization Cockpit (MDS_LOAD_COCKPIT)
    • Handling Errors with the Post Processing Office (PPO)
    • Practical Example: Resolving Common Synchronization Errors
    • Activating the BP to Customer/Vendor Synchronization
    • Finalizing Number Range and Field Status Settings
    • Overview of the Phased Approach
    • Phase 1: Preparation - The Foundation for Success
    • Phase 2: Synchronization - Bringing Your Data to Life
    • Phase 3: The S/4HANA Conversion (SUM Run)
    • Phase 4: Post-Conversion Activities
  6. The New Implementation (Greenfield) Journey
    • Configuration Essentials using Best Practices
    • Data Migration Tools and Techniques
  7. Impact on Integrations & Custom Solutions
    • Interfaces, IDocs, and Custom Code
    • Employee Integration (HCM)
    • SAP CRM Integration
    • Industry-Specific Solutions (Utilities & Retail)
  8. Business Case Study & End-User Test Plan
    • Scenario Overview: Global Tech Inc.'s S/4HANA Conversion
    • Test Case 1: Standard Customer Conversion and Validation
    • Test Case 2: Vendor with Contact Persons
    • Test Case 3: Merging a Customer and Vendor into a Single BP
    • Test Case 4: Error Handling and Resolution using PPO
  9. Appendix: Key Resources
    • Valuable SAP Notes
    • Helpful Documentation Links
  1. Introduction: The Big Change - What is CVI?

Welcome to the world of master data in SAP S/4HANA! If you've worked with SAP ERP (ECC) before, you're used to creating customers with one transaction (like XD01) and vendors with another (like XK01). In SAP S/4HANA, this has fundamentally changed.

Purpose and Scope of This Guide

This document is your friendly guide to understanding and navigating one of the most critical changes in SAP S/4HANA: Customer/Vendor Integration (CVI)1. We will demystify the concepts, walk you through the processes step-by-step, and provide practical examples and a full test plan you can use. Whether you're an end-user who creates customer records, a consultant configuring the system, or anyone in between, this guide is for you.

We will focus primarily on the System Conversion (Brownfield) scenario, which is relevant for the vast majority of companies moving from an existing SAP ERP system to SAP S/4HANA2.

Why CVI is Mandatory in SAP S/4HANA

In S/4HANA, the Business Partner (BP) is the one and only, or "single point of entry," for managing the master data of your customers and vendors3. You can no longer create a customer or a vendor without first creating a Business Partner. CVI is the automated process that ensures this rule is followed. It's the "glue" that synchronizes your Business Partner data with the underlying customer and vendor tables4.

Why the change? The old way had its problems. Imagine a company that is both your customer and your supplier. In the old system, you had to create two separate master records: one customer and one vendor. This led to redundant data, potential inconsistencies, and a fragmented view of your business relationship.

Goodbye Old Friends: The Limitations of Classic Customer/Vendor Master

The traditional customer and vendor objects in SAP ERP had several limitations that the Business Partner model solves5:

  • Redundant Data: General information like name and address had to be stored twice if a partner was both a customer and vendor.
  • Single Address: A customer or vendor could only have one standard address6. Managing multiple locations was cumbersome.
  • No Central Relationship: There was no standard way to link the customer record of a company to its vendor record7.
  • No Time-Dependency: You couldn't easily manage changes over time, like an address that is only valid for a future period8.

The Business Partner approach was designed to overcome all these challenges, providing a more flexible, centralized, and efficient way to manage master data.

  1. Meet the Business Partner (BP): Your New Single Source of Truth

The Business Partner (BP) is the strategic and mandatory object model in SAP S/4HANA for managing all your partners9. Think of the Business Partner as a central file or a main contact card for any person, organization, or group you do business with.

The Power of the Business Partner: Key Advantages

Adopting the BP model offers significant benefits10:

  • Single Legal Entity: A single legal entity is represented by one Business Partner, no matter how many roles it plays11.
  • Multiple Roles: One BP can be a customer, a vendor (supplier), a contact person, and more—all at the same time12.
  • Data Consolidation: General data (like name and address) is stored once and shared across all roles, reducing redundancy and making data maintenance easier13.
  • Multiple Addresses: A Business Partner can have multiple addresses (e.g., head office, delivery address, billing address), each with its own validity period14.
  • Flexible Relationships: You can define rich relationships between Business Partners, such as "is the contact person for," "is a subsidiary of," or even "is married to"15.
  • Time-Dependency: You can define validity periods for roles, addresses, bank details, and relationships, giving you a historical view of your data16.

Understanding BP Categories: Organization, Person, Group

Every Business Partner you create must belong to one of three categories17:

  1. Organization: Represents companies, government agencies, non-profits, etc. (e.g., SAP SE, Google). This is the most common category for customers and vendors.
  2. Person: Represents an individual human being (e.g., a specific contact person, a retail consumer, an employee).
  3. Group: Represents a shared entity like a married couple or a business consortium. This category is used less frequently.

The Role Concept: One Partner, Many Hats (Customer, Vendor, etc.)

The BP Role is what defines the business function of a partner. A BP is created with a general role, and then specific roles are added to enable business transactions.

  • A BP is created with general data (name, address).
  • To sell to this BP, you add the Customer role (e.g., FLCU01). This opens up the sales-specific data screens (sales area data).
  • If you also buy from this BP, you add the Vendor role (e.g., FLVN01). This opens up the purchasing-specific screens (purchasing organization data).

The same BP number is used for all functions. This is the core of the "single point of entry" concept.

  1. Business & Solution Impact: What This Means for You

The transition to the Business Partner model has a direct impact on daily operations, user interfaces, and system authorizations. Here’s what you need to know.

A New Way of Working: The BP Transaction and Fiori Apps

The single most important change for end-users is that all maintenance of customer and vendor master data now happens in one place.

  • The Single Point of Entry: The SAP GUI transaction BP is the central transaction to create, change, and display any Business Partner, regardless of its role (customer, vendor, etc.)18.
  • Modern Interface: SAP Fiori provides modern, web-based applications for managing customer and supplier data, offering a more intuitive user experience19.

Obsolete vs. Redirected Transactions: A Clear Guide

Many of the classic customer and vendor transactions you are familiar with from SAP ERP have been changed in S/4HANA.

Redirected Transactions:

If you try to use these old transaction codes, the system will automatically redirect you to the BP transaction20. Your muscle memory is safe!

  • XD01, XD02, XD03 (Central Customer) 21
  • XK01, XK02, XK03 (Central Vendor) 22
  • VD01, VD02, VD03 (Sales Area Customer) 23
  • MK01, MK02, MK03 (Purchasing Vendor) 24
  • FD01, FD02, FD03 (FI Customer) 25
  • FK01, FK02, FK03 (FI Vendor) 26
  • And many others...

Obsolete Transactions:

These transactions are no longer available in S/4HANA and have no direct replacement because their functions are handled within the BP transaction or other processes27.

  • VD06 (Deletion flag for customer - sales)
  • XD06 (Deletion flag for customer - central)
  • FK06 (Deletion flag for vendor - finance)
  • And others like MK06, MK12, MK18, MK19 28

Important Note: Even though you maintain the data through the BP transaction, business transactions like creating a sales order (VA01) or a purchase order (ME21N) still use the original Customer and Vendor numbers for selection29.

Master Data Quality: The #1 Prerequisite

CVI is a strict process. It requires high-quality master data to work correctly30. During synchronization, the system validates fields like tax numbers, bank details, and addresses against current configuration. Inconsistent or incorrectly formatted data will cause errors and prevent the Business Partner from being created.

It is strongly recommended to run data cleansing and consistency checks well in advance of the actual S/4HANA conversion project to identify and correct these issues31. If left until the last minute, data quality problems can become a major roadblock32.

Navigating the New User Interface with Fiori

SAP Fiori offers a modern, role-based user experience. For master data specialists, there are two key apps.

Fiori App: Manage Customer Master Data (F0850A)

This app allows you to centrally create, edit, display, search, and copy customer master data33.

Key Features:

  • Create & Edit: Use intuitive "Create Person" or "Create Organization" buttons and fill in data across tabs like Basic Data, Roles, and Address34343434.
  • Copy Functionality: A powerful feature, only available in Fiori, allows you to copy Sales Organization and Company Code data for the same customer master, saving significant time35.
  • Time Dependency: If enabled, you can set validity dates for roles, addresses, bank accounts, and contacts, providing a clear history of changes36.
  • Attachments: Easily attach relevant documents using Generic Object Services (GOS)37.

Fiori App: Manage Supplier Master Data (F1053A)

This app provides a parallel experience for managing your supplier (vendor) master data38.

Key Features:

  • Central Management: Create, edit, and manage all supplier information from one central place39.
  • Copy Functionality: Similar to the customer app, you can copy Purchasing Organization and Company Code data for the same supplier, a feature exclusive to Fiori40.
  • Time Dependency & Attachments: The same powerful features for managing data validity and attaching documents are available here as well41414141.

Understanding Authorizations in the BP World

While the existing authorization concepts for customer and vendor data (like authorization objects for company code and sales area) still apply, the Business Partner model introduces its own set of additional authorization objects42.

These objects give you granular control over who can access and change different parts of a Business Partner's data.

  • B_BUPA_GRP (Authorization Groups): Controls which BPs a user can edit based on the assigned authorization group43.
  • B_BUPA_RLT (BP Roles): Defines which BP roles a user is allowed to create or change44.
  • B_BUPA_FDG (Field Groups): Allows you to control display/change access to specific fields or sections of the BP transaction screen45.

For the CVI conversion process itself, specific authorizations are needed to run the tools and make the necessary customizing changes46.

  1. CVI Implementation Scenarios Explained

There are two primary paths for implementing CVI, depending on your company's S/4HANA adoption strategy47.

Greenfield (New Implementation): Starting Fresh

This scenario is like building a new house on an empty plot of land. You are implementing a brand new SAP S/4HANA system.

  • Process: In a Greenfield project, you configure the Business Partner and CVI settings from scratch48. You then migrate your existing customer and vendor data from legacy systems into S/4HANA as Business Partners49. The BP is created first, and the CVI process automatically creates the corresponding customer and/or vendor views in the background.
  • Tools: Data migration is typically handled using tools like the SAP S/4HANA Migration Cockpit or SAP Rapid Data Migration505050.

Brownfield (System Conversion): Migrating Your Existing System

This is the most common scenario, akin to renovating an existing house. You are converting your current SAP ERP (ECC) system to SAP S/4HANA.

  • Process: Before you can technically convert your system, you must first convert all your existing customers and vendors into Business Partners within your ECC system51. This is a mandatory pre-conversion step. The process involves preparation, data cleansing, customizing, and running a synchronization tool to create a BP for every existing customer and vendor.
  • Tools: This process is managed using a set of dedicated tools, chief among them the CVI Cockpit (CVI_COCKPIT) and the Synchronization Cockpit (MDS_LOAD_COCKPIT)525252.

This guide will now focus extensively on the Brownfield (System Conversion) journey, as it is the more complex and common path.

  1. The System Conversion (Brownfield) Journey: A Step-by-Step Guide

Converting an existing SAP ERP system requires a structured, phased approach to CVI. This is not something that should be done during the technical downtime of your S/4HANA conversion. SAP strongly recommends completing the CVI synchronization weeks or even months before the main conversion project to avoid surprises and delays53.

Overview of the Phased Approach

The entire process can be broken down into four main phases54:

  1. Preparation: In your existing ECC system, you perform data cleansing, activate necessary functions, and complete all required CVI customizing. This is the most labor-intensive phase.
  2. Synchronization: You use the Synchronization Cockpit to create a Business Partner for every existing customer and vendor in your ECC system.
  3. Conversion: This is the technical system upgrade to S/4HANA, performed by the technical team using the Software Update Manager (SUM).
  4. Post-Conversion: In your new S/4HANA system, you finalize the CVI configuration to make the Business Partner the leading object for all future master data maintenance.

Phase 1: Preparation - The Foundation for Success

This phase is critical. Thorough preparation ensures a smooth synchronization process. All these activities are performed in your current SAP ERP (ECC) system.

The CVI Cockpit: Your Central Command Center

SAP provides a central transaction, CVI_COCKPIT, to guide you through all the necessary steps in a logical sequence55. It acts as a project dashboard, bundling all the required activities and reports into one place and allowing you to track their status.

Transaction Code: CVI_COCKPIT

SAP Note for Implementation: 2832085 56

The cockpit is divided into tabs that mirror the project phases:

  • Read Me: Provides links to essential SAP Notes and documentation57.
  • Preparation: Contains tools for checking master data consistency and automating customizing checks58.
  • CVI Load: Manages the actual synchronization process59.
  • Upgrade Preparation: Includes final checks to be run just before the technical system conversion60.

Master Data Cleansing: The Master Data Consistency Check

Before you can synchronize, you must ensure your data is clean. The system will reject records with inconsistencies.

Transaction Code: CVI_PRECHK (or access via the CVI Cockpit) 61

This report checks for the most common master data errors that can block CVI synchronization, such as62:

  • Invalid tax numbers
  • Incorrectly formatted postal codes
  • Missing country codes
  • Inconsistent address data

The report not only identifies errors but also allows for correction. You can either jump directly to the customer/vendor maintenance transaction or, for certain errors, perform mass changes directly from the results list63.

Automated Customizing Checks

This tool checks if you have completed all the necessary CVI-related configuration settings.

Transaction Code: BP_CVI_IMG_CHK (Report: CVI_CUSTOMIZING_RESOLVE) 64

The report provides a list of checks. For any failed checks, it shows an error message and provides a direct link to the relevant customizing (SPRO) activity, making it easy to resolve issues65.

Archiving Data Marked for Deletion

Before starting the conversion, it is a good practice (though optional) to archive customers and vendors that are already marked for deletion66666666. This reduces the volume of data to be converted and can help clean up obsolete configuration settings67.

  • Archiving Object for Customers: FI_ACCRECV
  • Archiving Object for Vendors: FI_ACCPAYB

Critical Customizing for CVI Synchronization

The following configuration steps are mandatory and must be completed in your ECC system before running the synchronization. You can find these settings in the SAP Customizing Implementation Guide (IMG) via transaction SPRO.

Master Data Synchronization Setup

  1. Activate Creation of Post Processing Orders (PPO)

When a synchronization error occurs, the system creates a "Post Processing Order" so you can analyze and fix it later. You need to activate this functionality.

  • SPRO Path: Cross-Application Components -> General Application Functions -> Postprocessing Office -> Business Processes -> Activate Creation of Postprocessing Orders 68
  • Action: Activate the entries for business processes CVI_01 (Customer -> BP) and CVI_02 (Vendor -> BP)69.
  1. Activate PPO Requests for Platform Objects

This step tells the system to create a PPO request specifically when a Business Partner synchronization fails.

  • SPRO Path: Cross-Application Components -> Master Data Synchronization -> Synchronization Control -> Synchronization Control -> Activate PPO Requests for Platform Objects in the Dialog 70
  • Action: Create an entry for the Synchronization Object BP and check the "PPO Active" box71.
  1. Activate Synchronization Options

Here you define the direction of the synchronization. For the pre-conversion phase in ECC, you only activate the direction from Customer/Vendor to BP.

  • SPRO Path: Cross-Application Components -> Master Data Synchronization -> Synchronization Control -> Synchronization Control -> Activate Synchronization Options 72
  • Action: Activate the options for Source CUSTOMER -> Target BP and Source VENDOR -> Target BP73.

Number Ranges & Groupings: A Deep Dive with Examples

This is one of the most critical and complex configuration areas. Your goal is to define how Business Partner numbers will be assigned. SAP recommends keeping the BP number the same as the existing Customer/Vendor number whenever possible to avoid confusion74.

Key Concepts:

  • Customer/Vendor Account Groups: Control the number range for customers/vendors.
  • BP Groupings: Control the number range for Business Partners.
  • CVI Mapping: You must map each Customer/Vendor Account Group to a BP Grouping.

Scenario: Let's say your customers use an internal number range 01 (e.g., 100000 - 199999) and you want the BPs to have the same numbers.

Step-by-Step Configuration:

  1. Define BP Number Range:
    • SPRO Path: Cross-Application Components -> SAP Business Partner -> Business Partner -> Basic Settings -> Number Ranges and Groupings -> Define Number Ranges
    • Action: Create a new BP number range (e.g., C1) that is identical to the customer number range (100000 - 199999). Crucially, you must mark this number range as External75757575. This allows the synchronization process to assign a specific number (the old customer number) instead of drawing the next available number.
  2. Define BP Grouping:
    • SPRO Path: ... -> Number Ranges and Groupings -> Define Groupings and Assign Number Ranges
    • Action: Create a new BP Grouping (e.g., CUST) and assign your new external number range (C1) to it76. It's good practice to create a unique BP Grouping for each Customer/Vendor Account Group you want to map77.
  3. Define Number Assignment for CVI:
    • SPRO Path: Cross-Application Components -> Master Data Synchronization -> Customer/Vendor Integration -> Business Partner Settings -> Settings for Customer Integration -> Field Assignment for Customer Integration -> Assign Keys -> Define Number Assignment for Direction Customer to BP 78
    • Action: Create an entry that maps your Customer Account Group (e.g., DEBI) to your new BP Grouping (CUST). Most importantly, check the "Same numbers" checkbox79. This tells the CVI process to use the customer's number as the BP's number.

What if my Customer and Vendor number ranges overlap?

If you have a customer 1001 and a vendor 1001 who are different entities, you cannot use the same number for both BPs80. In this case, you must decide which one gets to keep the number. For the other, you'll need to map it to a BP Grouping with an internal number range, and the system will assign a new, different BP number.

Value Mapping for Customers & Contact Persons

Many fields in the customer master are based on customizing tables (e.g., departments, functions for contact persons). The Business Partner has its own, separate customizing tables for these fields. You must create a mapping between the old values and the new ones.

Example: Mapping Contact Person Departments

  • SPRO Path: ... -> Customer/Vendor Integration -> Business Partner Settings -> Settings for Customer Integration -> Field Assignment for Customer Integration -> Assign Attributes -> Contact Person -> Assign Department Numbers for Contact Person 81
  • Action: For every department code used in the customer contact person data (e.g., code 0002 for "Purchasing"), you must map it to the corresponding department code in the BP settings (e.g., code 0002 for "Purchasing Manager")82.
  • You must perform similar mapping for:
    • Contact Person Functions 83
    • Contact Person Authority 84
    • Marital Statuses 85
    • Legal Forms to Legal Status 86
    • Industries 87

Phase 2: Synchronization - Bringing Your Data to Life

Once all preparation and customizing are complete, you are ready to run the initial data load. This process reads your customer and vendor master data and creates the corresponding Business Partners.

Using the Synchronization Cockpit (MDS_LOAD_COCKPIT)

This is the central tool for executing the mass synchronization.

Transaction Code: MDS_LOAD_COCKPIT (or access via the CVI Cockpit's "CVI Load" tab) 88

How to Execute a Run:

  1. Select Synchronization Process (1): In the top-left pane, double-click the process you want to run, for example, Customer -> Business Partner89.
  2. Set Control Parameters (2): You can define the Block Size (how many records are processed in one chunk) and specify Background Processing for large volumes90. It's recommended to run this in the background with parallel processing to improve performance91.
  3. Enter Selection Criteria (3): In the bottom pane, specify which records to synchronize. You can filter by customer/vendor number range, account group, etc.92. Best Practice: Start with a very small, manageable number of records (1-10) to test your configuration and resolve any initial errors before running the full load93.
  4. Execute: Press F8 to start the synchronization.
  5. Monitor: Switch to the "Monitor" tab to see the status of your runs. A green light means success; a red light indicates errors have occurred94949494.

Handling Errors with the Post Processing Office (PPO)

When a synchronization run fails for one or more records, you need to find out why and fix the problem. The Post Processing Office (PPO) is the tool for this.

Transaction Code: MDS_PPO2 (or click the "Call PPO" button from the MDS_LOAD_COCKPIT monitor) 95959595

The PPO shows you a list of all failed synchronization orders. You can drill down into each order to see the specific error messages.

Practical Example: Resolving Common Synchronization Errors

Let's walk through resolving a typical error using the PPO.

Scenario: You run the synchronization for a customer, and it fails.

  1. Identify the Error: You go to the PPO (MDS_PPO2) and see an order with the error message: "Form of address 0002 not designated for organizations"96.
  2. Analyze the Cause: This is a classic customizing error. The CVI process tries to create the BP as an "Organization." However, the form of address used in the customer master (e.g., "Mr.") is only configured for "Persons" in the BP settings97.
  3. Resolve the Customizing Error:
    • Go to the relevant SPRO path: Cross-Application Components -> SAP Business Partner -> Business Partner -> Basic Settings -> Forms of Address -> Maintain Form of Address98.
    • Find the entry for "Mr." (Key 0002) and check the box for "Org." to allow it to be used for organizations99. Note: In a real project, you might instead activate a BAdI to automatically create such records as category "Person" instead of "Organization".
  4. Re-process the Order:
    • Go back to the PPO error entry.
    • Click the "Individual Synchronization" or "Mass Synchronization" button to re-run the process for the failed record(s)100.
  5. Check for New Errors: The first error is now resolved, but a second error appears for the same customer: "Email address is invalid"101.
    • This is a master data quality issue. The email address stored in the customer master does not follow a valid format.
  6. Resolve the Master Data Error:
    • From within the PPO order, on the "Customer" tab, click "Change"102. This takes you directly to the customer master data transaction (XD02).
    • Correct the invalid email address and save the customer103.
    • Because you saved the customer master while CVI synchronization was active, the system automatically re-synchronized it in the background. The BP is now created successfully.
  7. Complete the PPO Order: Go back to the PPO and manually set the status of the resolved order to "Complete" to clean up the error log104.

Phase 3: The S/4HANA Conversion (SUM Run)

This phase involves the technical upgrade of your system from SAP ERP to SAP S/4HANA using the Software Update Manager (SUM) tool. From a CVI perspective, the main prerequisite is that all customers, vendors, and their contact persons must be successfully converted to Business Partners before you begin this phase105. The SUM tool includes a pre-check that will stop the conversion if this requirement is not met. No additional CVI-specific actions are required during the technical conversion itself106.

Phase 4: Post-Conversion Activities

After your system is successfully converted to SAP S/4HANA, you need to perform a few final configuration steps to make the Business Partner the leading object and enable the synchronization from BP to the customer/vendor tables.

  1. Activate Synchronization Direction BP to Customer/Vendor
  • SPRO Path: Cross-Application Components -> Master Data Synchronization -> Synchronization Control -> Synchronization Control -> Activate Synchronization Options 107
  • Action: Now, activate the options for Source BP -> Target CUSTOMER and Source BP -> Target VENDOR108. You can deactivate the old C/V -> BP directions as they are no longer used109.
  1. Set BP Role Categories for Integration

This step tells the system that when a BP is created or changed with a specific role, it should trigger the creation or update of the corresponding customer/vendor record.

  • SPRO Path (Customer): ... -> Customer/Vendor Integration -> Business Partner Settings -> Settings for Customer Integration -> Set BP Role Category for Direction BP to Customer 110
  • Action (Customer): Add entries for the role categories FLCU00 (FI Customer) and FLCU01 (Customer)111.
  • SPRO Path (Vendor): ... -> Settings for Vendor Integration -> Set BP Role Category for Direction BP to Vendor 112
  • Action (Vendor): Add entries for FLVN00 (FI Vendor) and FLVN01 (Vendor).
  1. Define Number Assignment BP to Customer/Vendor

If you opted for same-numbering, you now need to configure the system to ensure that when a new BP is created, the customer/vendor record it generates also gets the same number.

  • SPRO Path: ... -> Assign Keys -> Define Number Assignment for Direction BP to Customer 113
  • Action:
    • Set the number range for the relevant Customer/Vendor Account Group to External. This allows the CVI process to pass the BP number to it.
    • In the mapping between the BP Grouping and the Account Group, ensure the "Same number" flag is checked.
    • Set the BP Grouping's number range to Internal so that new BPs are numbered automatically114.
  1. Adjust Field Status

The field status (optional, required, display, hidden) was previously controlled by the Customer/Vendor Account Group. In S/4HANA, this is controlled via the Business Partner settings. To ensure that your old settings are still respected in the BP transaction, you need to implement SAP Note 2516606115.

  1. The New Implementation (Greenfield) Journey

If you are starting with a fresh SAP S/4HANA installation, the CVI process is much simpler because you don't have to convert existing data.

Configuration Essentials using Best Practices

In a new implementation, your primary task is to configure the Business Partner object and the CVI settings to meet your business requirements116. SAP provides Best Practice Building Blocks that contain pre-configured settings to accelerate this process117.

  • BN4 (Basic Settings for Business Partners): Provides core BP settings like roles, number ranges, and groupings118.
  • J61 (Central Configuration for Business Partners): Includes settings for using BPs as customers and vendors, and the CVI interface settings to link them119119119119.

You would use these building blocks as a starting point and adjust them as needed. The configuration for number ranges, groupings, and value mapping is conceptually the same as in the Brownfield scenario, but you have more freedom in designing the setup from scratch.

Data Migration Tools and Techniques

Once the configuration is complete, you need to load your master data from your old systems (which could be non-SAP systems or older SAP systems).

  • SAP S/4HANA Migration Cockpit: This is the standard, built-in tool for migrating data into S/4HANA120. It provides pre-defined templates for various data objects, including Business Partners (Customers/Suppliers). You fill the templates with your legacy data and the cockpit handles the validation and loading process.
  • SAP Rapid Data Migration: A more comprehensive solution for complex migration projects, leveraging SAP Data Services121.
  • Interfaces (IDoc/SOA): For ongoing integration with other systems, you must use the standard interfaces like the Business Partner SOA Service or IDocs (DEBMAS/CREMAS)122122122122. Direct updates to the underlying tables are not supported.
  1. Impact on Integrations & Custom Solutions

The switch to the Business Partner model also affects custom code and integrations with other systems.

Interfaces, IDocs, and Custom Code

  • Custom Code: Any custom programs that used Batch Input (CALL TRANSACTION) to create or change customers/vendors (e.g., XD01, XK01) must be rewritten123. The new standard is to use the official API for Business Partner maintenance: CL_MD_BP_MAINTAIN124.
  • IDocs DEBMAS/CREMAS: These IDoc types are still available in S/4HANA for interfacing with external systems. However, the inbound processing has been redesigned to work with the CVI framework, where the BP is the leading object125.
  • RFCs: Certain older RFC function modules for master data integration are no longer supported and must be replaced with the new APIs or services126.

Employee Integration (HCM)

In S/4HANA, employees used in business processes (e.g., as sales employees, or employees who are also vendors for travel expenses) must also be represented as Business Partners127.

  • A specific migration report, /SHCM/RH_SYNC_BUPA_FROM_EMPL, must be executed after the S/4HANA conversion to create BPs for all your HCM employees128.
  • These BPs are typically created with the "Employee" role and, if necessary, the "Vendor" role. This process is separate from the main customer/vendor CVI synchronization.
  • For detailed guidance, refer to SAP Note 2340095129.

SAP CRM Integration

If you have an SAP CRM system integrated with your ERP, the CVI conversion requires special attention to ensure the link between the systems is not broken. The Business Partners in both systems are linked by a unique identifier (GUID).

  • Crucial Prerequisite: Before you start the CVI mass synchronization in ECC, you must implement specific BAdIs and correction reports provided by SAP130. These ensure that when BPs are created in ECC, they are created with the same GUID as their counterparts in CRM.
  • Failure to do this will irretrievably break the mapping between the systems131.
  • The leading SAP Note for this topic, which contains all necessary steps and links to other notes, is 2285062132.

Industry-Specific Solutions (Utilities & Retail)

  • SAP IS-U (Utilities): This industry solution has its own specific process and reports for handling the CVI conversion. You cannot use the standard MDS_LOAD_COCKPIT133. You must use the reports REU_CVI_CUST_LINK and REU_CVI_EKUN_TO_BUTOID134. Refer to SAP Note 2344100 for details135.
  • SAP IS-R (Retail): For retail customers, the "Site Master" data (representing stores, distribution centers) also needs to be converted to Business Partners. This is a special process. Refer to SAP Note 2310884 for specific instructions136.
  1. Business Case Study & End-User Test Plan

This section provides a practical test plan designed to validate the CVI conversion process. It can be used by key users and project team members to ensure the configuration is correct and the system behaves as expected.

Scenario Overview: Global Tech Inc.'s S/4HANA Conversion

Global Tech Inc. is a manufacturing company converting its SAP ERP 6.0 system to SAP S/4HANA. They need to test the CVI process thoroughly in a sandbox environment before converting their production system. The test plan will cover key master data scenarios.

Test Case 1: Standard Customer Conversion and Validation

Objective: To verify that a standard domestic customer is successfully converted to a Business Partner with the same number and that subsequent business processes work correctly.

  1. Preparation (Master Data Creation):
  • In the ECC sandbox system, use transaction XD01 to create a new customer.
    • Name: Test Customer CVI
    • Address: A complete and valid address for your country.
    • Tax Number: A valid tax number.
    • Account Group: DEBI (or your equivalent for domestic customers)
    • Company Code: Your test company code (e.g., 1000)
    • Sales Area: Your test sales area (e.g., 1000/10/00)
    • Example Data:
    • Note down the assigned customer number (e.g., 100250).
  1. Execution:
  • Run the Master Data Consistency Check (CVI_PRECHK) for customer 100250 to ensure there are no data quality issues.
  • Run the Synchronization Cockpit (MDS_LOAD_COCKPIT) for the single customer 100250.
  1. Verification:
  • Check the monitor in MDS_LOAD_COCKPIT. The run should have a green status.
  • Go to transaction BP. Search for Business Partner 100250.
  • Confirm that the BP was created with the correct name and address.
  • Check that the BP has the correct roles assigned (e.g., General Business Partner, FI Customer, Customer).
  • Check the link table using transaction SE16 for table CVI_CUST_LINK. Verify that there is an entry linking Customer 100250 to BP 100250.
  • End-to-End Test: Go to transaction VA01, create a standard sales order, and use 100250 as the Sold-to Party. The system should find the partner and allow you to proceed. This confirms that downstream processes are unaffected.

Test Case 2: Vendor with Contact Persons

Objective: To verify that a vendor and its associated contact persons are correctly converted into linked Business Partners.

  1. Preparation (Master Data Creation):
  • In the ECC sandbox, use transaction XK01 to create a new vendor (e.g., V-5010).
  • In transaction XK02 (Change Vendor), go to the "Contact persons" screen and create two contact persons for this vendor:
    • Contact 1: John Smith
    • Contact 2: Jane Doe
  1. Execution:
  • Run the Synchronization Cockpit (MDS_LOAD_COCKPIT) for the single vendor V-5010.
  1. Verification:
  • Go to transaction BP. Search for Business Partner V-5010.
  • Confirm the BP was created as an Organization.
  • Go to the "Relationships" tab.
  • Verify that there are two "Has Contact Person" relationships, one for John Smith and one for Jane Doe.
  • Double-click on one of the contact persons. This should navigate you to a new Business Partner (with a different, internally assigned number) created for that person, with the category Person.

Test Case 3: Merging a Customer and Vendor into a Single BP

Objective: To test the scenario where a single legal entity is both a customer and a vendor, ensuring they are merged into one BP.

  1. Preparation (Master Data & BAdI):
  • Ensure the logic from SAP Note 2363892 (or a custom equivalent) is active to facilitate the merge137.
  • Use XD01 to create a new customer (e.g., 990100).
  • Use XK01 to create a new vendor. In the control data screen, link it to the customer you just created by entering 990100 in the "Customer" field. Note the vendor number (e.g., V-9901).
  1. Execution:
  • Run MDS_LOAD_COCKPIT for customer 990100 first.
  • After it completes successfully, run MDS_LOAD_COCKPIT for vendor V-9901.
  1. Verification:
  • Go to transaction BP. Search for Business Partner 990100.
  • In the "Roles" dropdown, verify that the BP has both a Customer role (e.g., FLCU01) and a Vendor role (e.g., FLVN01).
  • Check the link tables. CVI_CUST_LINK should link customer 990100 to BP 990100. CVI_VEND_LINK should link vendor V-9901 to the same BP 990100.

Test Case 4: Error Handling and Resolution using PPO

Objective: To simulate a data quality error and test the correction process using the Post Processing Office.

  1. Preparation (Master Data Creation):
  • Using XD01, create a customer (e.g., ERR-100) with a deliberately invalid postal code for its country (e.g., a 6-digit code for Germany).
  1. Execution:
  • Run MDS_LOAD_COCKPIT for customer ERR-100.
  1. Verification and Correction:
  • In the MDS_LOAD_COCKPIT monitor, confirm the run has a red status.
  • Click the "Call PPO" button to navigate to the Post Processing Office.
  • Find the error order for ERR-100. Double-click it to see the error message (e.g., "Postal Code must have length 5").
  • On the "Customer" tab within the PPO order, click "Change".
  • The system takes you to XD02. Correct the postal code and Save.
  • Go back to the PPO order. Click the "Individual Synchronization" button. The synchronization should now run successfully.
  • Set the PPO order status to "Complete".
  • Go to transaction BP and confirm that Business Partner ERR-100 now exists.
  1. Appendix: Key Resources

This section provides a curated list of essential SAP Notes and documentation links referenced throughout this guide to support your CVI project.

Valuable SAP Notes

New Customizing Check Report for SAP S/4HANA Master Data Migration (BP<->CVI) 142

Helpful Documentation Links

  • SAP Help: Introduce Business Partner Approach 149
  • SAP Help: Customer Vendor Integration 150
  • SAP Help: Master Data Synchronization 151

entry.title: Facing issue while cost run ML4HMASTER106 Close previous period for material
entry.content:
Dear SAP Team,

While cost run for period 006 we are facing  below issue  in preparation phase

Application Area      Message      Number         Error Message Text                                                 Material                 Plant     Material type

ML4HMASTER             106             1            Close previous period for material 


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: Facing issue while cost run ML4HMASTER106 Close previ...
entry.content:
1. Select the previous period that needs to be closed:

Example: If you're trying to close period 10/2025 and getting ML4HMASTER106
You need to close period 09/2025 first

2. If it's not allowed or you don't care about period 09/2025 anymore, you can set "Allow Open Status for Previous Period" on in the parameter setting of preparation step of Edit Actual Costing Run.

Then the error will be skipped.

 

Check further details:

3648497- Allow Open Status for Previous Period checkbox in Actual Costing - SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud https://me.sap.com/notes/3648497

entry.title: Re: Offset days calculation for Performance based Mainten...
entry.content:
Hello jaya,

Based on the details of your performance-based maintenance plan (Annual Estimate = 1000, Cycle = 72, Last Counter Reading = 150) and the standard scheduling logic in SAP, the 26 offset days are automatically calculated by the system as the expected duration to reach the next maintenance point. Here is the breakdown:

Calculation of the Offset Days
The system uses the following formula to determine the interval until the next planned maintenance date:

Calculate Daily Performance:
Daily Performance = Annual Estimate / 365
1000 / 365 ≈ 2.74 (units per day)

Determine the Next Maintenance Point:
Next Planned Counter Reading = Last Counter Reading + Cycle Length
150 + 72 = 222

Calculate the Required Days (Offset):
Offset Days = (Next Planned Counter Reading - Last Counter Reading) / Daily Performance
(222 - 150) / 2.74 ≈ 26.3 Days

The system uses this result to schedule the call object, indicating that the next maintenance is expected in approximately 26 days based on the estimated usage .

 Additional Context
Nature of this Offset: This automatically calculated "offset" represents the expected timeline. It is different from the manual offset values you can enter in a maintenance strategy to adjust the first due date of a maintenance package .

Data Accuracy: Please ensure the "Annual Estimate" accurately reflects the equipment's typical usage pattern, as it directly impacts the scheduling accuracy.

I hope this clarifies how the system derives the value. Please feel free to ask if you have any further questions.

Best regards,

entry.title: Re: How to Automate Sales Order Quantity Based on Custom...
entry.content:
Hello @VA19 

You can not directly auto-write the standard item quantity from a Cloud BAdI based on header custom fields. In Public Cloud, the sales-document BAdIs allow you to set custom fields, but changing standard fields like quantity is not supported in-app. SAP Support Portal/2733433 - BAdI option to set-change values in standard sales fields in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

If quantities are to be set automatically, this can be done side-by-side after saving. Business events can be used to trigger actions when an order is created or modified, followed by invoking the public Sales Order API to update the item's requested quantity (using PATCH). Sales Order events (Created/Changed) are available for S/4HANA Cloud and are intended for use in this scenario.SAP Business Accelerator Hub-Sales Order Events. The Sales Order A2X API documentation includes the Update Sales Order Item (PATCH) method. This is the supported method to modify standard fields like quantity programmatically.  SAP Help Portal-APIs for Sales-Update Sales Order Item

Recommendation: Cloud-compatible Design

  • Keep the other Dequan Xu’s steps for creating header custom fields in Custom Fields & Logic (good).
  • Do not set RequestedQuantity in a Cloud BAdI; SAP restricts changes to standard sales fields within the app.SAP Support Portal

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Безкоштовне навчання від SAP: ще більше можливостей для розвитку
entry.content:
SAP Ukraine розширює освітні ініціативи та відкриває доступ до безкоштовних програм і ресурсів для всіх, хто прагне розвиватися у сфері сучасних технологій.

На платформі SAP Learning зібрані актуальні курси, навчальні матеріали та відео, які допомагають опановувати бізнес-процеси, аналітику, автоматизацію та хмарні рішення. Контент постійно оновлюється експертами, щоб відповідати сучасним трендам.

💡 Серед можливостей для навчання:

  • SAP Learning Journeys — покрокові навчальні маршрути від UX і розробки до аналітики та роботи з даними.

  • Пробні середовища SAP (Business Technology Platform, Business Data Cloud, S/HANA Cloud, Build Apps, Analytics Cloud) — щоб не лише читати про можливості, а й працювати з ними на практиці.

  • SAP Learning Hub, Internal Edition — доступ до практичних вправ, живих сесій з експертами та до чотирьох безкоштовних спроб скласти сертифікаційний іспит SAP.

  • Career Corner — вакансії та можливості розвитку у глобальній екосистемі SAP.

  • YouTube-канал SAP з пояснювальними відео Explore the world of SAP, де складні теми подаються легко й доступно.

Особливу увагу SAP приділяє студентам і викладачам, які можуть безкоштовно користуватися навчальними ресурсами, долучатися до освітніх програм і отримувати сертифікацію. Долучайтесь!

 

А які з цих ресурсів були корисні вам?

entry.title: Re: AATP Supply Protection
entry.content:
Hello,
as mentioned before the consumption of protection only happens in the matching time bucket. This can lead to there is one time bucket with a high remaining protection and the other time bucket has consumed its protection multiple times.
There are options to distribute the consumption within a protection group, so that the consumption of the matching bucket is used, but if the consumption exceeds the protection, the next time bucket is taken to assign the consumption.
This can be done with the BAdI "ATP Supply Protection - Redistribution of Consumption" ATP_SUP_REDISTRIBUTE_CNSMPN; (https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_ON-PREMISE/f132c385e0234fe68ae9ff35b2da178c/bac178999f934d549612ba9beec4e90f.html)
Perhaps this is helpful.

entry.title: Stay Current with SAP SuccessFactors Talent Intelligence Hub - 2H 2025 Release Updates
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community!

The 2H 2025 release for SAP SuccessFactors brings exciting enhancements to Talent Intelligence Hub (TIH), reinforcing SAP's commitment to AI-powered skills management and seamless talent development. This release focuses on intelligent automation, enhanced user experiences, and deeper integration across the talent ecosystem.

Let me walk you through the key updates that will transform how organizations manage skills and attribute data.

1. AI-Assisted Skills Identification from Resume

One of the most anticipated features this release is the ability to extract skills directly from resumes using AI. Employees can now upload their resume through the Add from Resume option in the Growth Portfolio, and the system automatically:

  • Analyzes resume content using SAP SuccessFactors universal skills taxonomy
  • Identifies relevant skills and matches them against your Attributes Library
  • Displays matched skills for employee review and approval
  • Adds selected skills to the Growth Portfolio with proper tracking

What you need: AI units license, enabled Assisted Skills Identification setting, and standardized skills in your Attributes Library.

 

2. AI-Assisted Skills Inference Now Includes Descriptions

Building on existing AI capabilities, skills inference now goes beyond just skill names. When you use AI-assisted features to infer skills into the Attributes Library, the system automatically:

  • Pulls skill descriptions from the SAP SuccessFactors skills taxonomy
  • Adds both name and description simultaneously
  • Reduces manual effort for administrators

This enhancement ensures more accurate and comprehensive skill data while saving valuable administrative time.

3. AI-Assisted Skills Standardization - Now Generally Available

After a successful early adoption phase, AI-assisted skills standardization is now generally available with significant enhancements:

New Features:

  • Map multiple skills in TIH to a single standard name in the universal taxonomy
  • Two new fields: Standardization Status and Proposed Name
  • Enhanced visibility directly in the Manage Talent Intelligence Hub interface

Standardization Status Values:

  • Pending Review - Job has run, awaiting administrator action
  • Standardized - Skill mapped to standard taxonomy name
  • Standardized (alternate name) - Mapped but using custom name
  • Custom - No standard taxonomy match found

This feature helps organizations reduce complexity, eliminate duplicates, and maintain consistent skill naming conventions across the enterprise.

4. Automatic Sync from Development Goals

Attributes are now automatically synchronized between Development Goals and the Growth Portfolio. When employees link an attribute to a development goal, if that attribute isn't already in their Growth Portfolio, it's automatically added. The Timeline section clearly indicates the source as "added from development goal."

This enhancement eliminates manual duplication and ensures consistency across talent development activities.

5. Recruiting Skills Transfer to Growth Portfolio

Skills assessed during the recruitment process now follow candidates into their employee journey. When a candidate moves to Hired status, skills evaluated during interviews and matched to job requisitions are automatically transferred to their Growth Portfolio.

Important Notes:

  • Only skill names transfer; proficiency levels require manual updates
  • Supported for: Recruiting → Employee Central and Recruiting & Onboarding → Employee Central
  • Not supported for Onboarding 1.0

This creates a complete skills profile from day one, ensuring valuable assessment data isn't lost in the transition.

Available: November 14, 2025

 6. Bookmark Experience for Learning Cards

The Growth Portfolio now includes bookmark functionality for Learning cards, creating a consistent experience between Growth Portfolio and Learning. Employees can:

  • Bookmark learning items from the Growth Portfolio
  • Access bookmarked items from the Learning page
  • View recently bookmarked items first
  • Remove bookmarks as needed

Bookmarking syncs bidirectionally between Growth Portfolio and Learning (and Opportunity Marketplace if enabled), providing flexibility for employees to plan their learning journey.

Available: November 14, 2025

7. Custom Attributes Support for Job Roles

A game-changer for organizations using custom attributes! You can now map custom attributes created in TIH to job roles in Job Profile Builder.

How it works:

  • Navigate to Manage Job Profile Content
  • Use the new Mapped Attributes tab
  • Select custom attributes from the attribute picker
  • Attributes automatically inherit to all employees with that role

Example: If 1,500 employees have the "Senior Engineer" role, and you map the custom attribute "System Design" to that role, all 1,500 employees automatically receive this attribute in their Growth Portfolio.

Note: Custom attributes aren't yet supported in the latest career worksheet.

8. Advanced Filtering and Sorting in Growth Portfolio

Employees and managers gain powerful new ways to navigate attributes with enhanced filtering and sorting options.

New Filters:

  • Proficiency Level - Filter by configured proficiency levels
  • Categories - Role-Related, Goal-Aligned, Marked as Passionate, Pending Approval, Last Modified by Me/Others
  • Tags - Filter by predefined and custom tags
  • Last Updated - Time-based filtering (7 days, 30 days, 3 months, 6 months, 1 year, or custom range)

Sorting Options:

  • Name
  • Last Modified
  • Proficiency Level
  • Proficiency Gap

These enhancements available in both individual Growth Portfolio view and Team View provide greater flexibility for managing and reviewing attributes.

9. TIH and Job Profile Builder Enabled by Default

New tenant configurations now automatically enable:

  • Talent Intelligence Hub
  • Job Profile Builder

This replaces the previous default of Job Description Manager, streamlining the setup process and reducing dependencies on multiple data sources. Note that Growth Portfolio still requires manual enablement.

Available: September 12, 2025

10. Proficiency Level Scale Changes Support

Administrators now have the flexibility to change proficiency level scales associated with attribute types, even after Growth Portfolio enablement.

How to use:

  1. Disable Growth Portfolio
  2. Navigate to attribute type in TIH
  3. Click the new Change Scale button
  4. Link new proficiency level scale

Critical Note: Changing scales removes all custom proficiency level scales cloned from the old scale. Data is preserved in other SuccessFactors modules but removed from TIH and Growth Portfolio. SAP recommends testing this feature in preview environments first.

 Key Takeaways for Implementation

  1. AI Units License Required - Most AI-powered features require AI units purchase
  2. Role-Based Permissions - Ensure appropriate permissions are configured for administrators and users
  3. Skills Standardization - Complete skills standardization before leveraging AI-assisted resume parsing
  4. Test in Preview - Test proficiency scale changes in preview environments
  5. User Training - Communicate new features to employees, especially resume upload and enhanced filtering

 Release Timeline

  • September 12, 2025 - TIH/Job Profile Builder default enablement
  • November 14, 2025 - Most AI and synchronization features
  • December 18, 2025 - Enhanced filtering and proficiency scale changes

The 2H 2025 release demonstrates SAP's continued investment in intelligent skills management and user experience. These enhancements streamline administrative workflows, provide employees with powerful self-service capabilities, and ensure skills data flows seamlessly across the talent lifecycle.

For detailed implementation guidance, refer to the official SAP Help Portal documentation linked with each feature. SAP SuccessFactors What's New 

Additional Blogs

PMGM 2H 2025 Release blog - Performance and Goal Management: 2H 2025 Updates 

SP 2H 2025 Release blog -  Succession Planning – 2H 2025 

CDP 2H 2025 Release blog - Career Development Planning – 2H 2025 

 Please feel free to share your ideas and questions in the comment box of this blog. I’d be glad to share what I know with you. Also, do share your thoughts on the latest changes and the features you valued the most. Share this blog with your colleagues.

Thank you!!

entry.title: Re: Change message type ME175 in ME35K
entry.content:
Why OMAS didn’t work is because, OMAS (Message Control Customizing) only affects messages that are explicitly coded to be configurable. ME175 is hardcoded in the standard logic and not linked to OMAS configuration, so changes there won’t affect its behavior.

To change message ME175 from an error to a warning in ME35K (S/4HANA), you’ll need to implement an implicit enhancement in program SAPLMLSP, specifically in function module ME_MESSAGE_STORE or ME_MESSAGE_HANDLER, as no standard BADI or user-exit is triggered for this scenario.

entry.title: Re: Stock Transfer of Project stock
entry.content:
In SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, direct stock transfer between projects after goods have been issued is not supported through standard functionality.

Why direct transfer is not available is because, Project stock (Q-stock) is tightly linked to the WBS element it was issued to. Once goods are issued to a project, they cannot be reassigned to another WBS element via a simple transfer posting. This restriction is due to strict accounting and ownership controls in the cloud environment.

Below would be the workaround options

Option-1
Step 1: Post a goods return from the original project (WBS element) back to unrestricted stock.

Step 2: Post a new goods issue to the target project (new WBS element).

This ensures proper accounting and audit trail.

Option-2
If the original issue was recent and still reversible, use transaction MIGO to reverse the material document. Then reissue to the correct project.

entry.title: Re: How to update completed inspection lots of current st...
entry.content:
SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud does not support direct modification of completed inspection lots to reflect updated inspection profiles. The recommended approach is to reverse usage decisions (UD), reprocess the lots, or create new ones via stock movement—but this remains a manual workaround.

Below are the workaround options

Go to transaction QA12 to reverse the UD for each inspection lot. This reopens the lot for editing, but only if no follow-on documents (e.g., delivery, invoice) are posted.

If possible, reverse the stock posting (e.g., via MBST or MIGO) to move stock back to unrestricted or quality inspection. This allows creation of a new inspection lot under the updated profile.

If batches are still in stock, consider enabling batch-specific inspection in the material master. This allows inspection lots to be created per batch, even for existing stock, using the updated profile.

Of course, as you have already been moving the stock to type 89, trigger new inspection lots, and regenerate CoA. This is the most reliable method but operationally heavy.

So with the above, your strategic approach would be

Use dynamic inspection rules: If your inspection profile is frequently updated, consider using dynamic inspection rules or conditional characteristics that adapt based on batch or date.

Leverage Quality Info Records: These can help control inspection setup per vendor/material combination.

entry.title: A importância de utilizar o Trace em iFlows com OData
entry.content:
O uso do Trace nos iFlows é uma prática essencial para garantir visibilidade, controle e eficiência nas integrações que utilizam OData Services. Em cenários de integração com sistemas como o SAP Business One, S/4HANA ou SuccessFactors, o OData é frequentemente usado para consultas, inserções e atualizações de dados — operações que exigem precisão e monitoramento detalhado.

Por que o Trace é importante

 

  1. Diagnóstico detalhado de erros O Trace permite visualizar o conteúdo completo das mensagens em cada etapa do iFlow. Isso é fundamental para identificar falhas na comunicação OData, como:
  2. Transparência nas transformações de dados Durante o processamento, o iFlow pode aplicar várias transformações — como Content Modifier, Message Mapping e Groovy Scripts. O Trace mostra como cada etapa altera o payload, permitindo validar se os dados enviados ao endpoint OData estão corretos.
  3. Redução do tempo de troubleshooting Sem o Trace, identificar a origem de um problema pode exigir múltiplas execuções e logs incompletos. Com o Trace ativo, é possível analisar o fluxo completo de uma única execução e resolver o problema com agilidade.
  4. Auditoria e rastreabilidade O Trace oferece um histórico técnico de como as mensagens foram processadas. Isso é especialmente importante em ambientes corporativos com exigências de auditoria, conformidade ou qualidade de dados.
  5. Validação de performance e payloads grandes Ao testar integrações OData que envolvem grandes volumes de dados ou múltiplas entidades, o Trace ajuda a entender gargalos e o comportamento do sistema sob carga.

 

Boas práticas ao usar o Trace

 

  • Ativar o Trace apenas durante testes e diagnósticos  não em produção por longos períodos, pois ele consome mais recursos.
  • Sempre analisar o payload antes e depois de chamadas OData, para confirmar que o formato e os dados estão corretos.
  • Documentar os principais cenários encontrados nos Traces para uso futuro da equipe.

 

 

XML do Odata que foi convertido para Json

 

IFlow Completo

 

O objetivo do iFlow é fazer uma chamada OData, converter e ajustar a resposta, e então finalizar o processo possivelmente enviando os dados para outro sistema ou armazenando para uso posterior.

Fluxo geral: Início → Montagem da requisição → Chamada OData → Conversão e tratamento → Fim

🔹 1. Início do iFlow

Este é o trigger (ponto de entrada). Pode ser acionado manualmente, por evento ou por outro sistema. Ele inicia o processo de integração.

🔹 2. “Creat Body” (Content Modifier)

Responsável por criar o corpo (payload) da requisição OData. Aqui normalmente se define um JSON ou XML com os dados que serão enviados ao endpoint OData.

👉 Exemplo:

{
  "CardCode": "C0001",
  "CardName": "Cliente Exemplo"
}

Se o iFlow faz uma operação POST ou PATCH, este bloco é essencial para montar o corpo da mensagem.

🔹 3. “Create Header” (Content Modifier)

Define os headers HTTP necessários para a chamada OData. Por exemplo:

 

  • Content-Type: application/json
  • Accept: application/json
  • Authorization: Basic … (se estiver usando autenticação básica)

 

Esses cabeçalhos garantem que o serviço OData entenda corretamente a requisição.

🔹 4. “Request Reply 1”

Este componente faz a chamada ao serviço OData. É onde o CPI realmente se comunica com o destino configurado (no caso, o componente “OData” mostrado abaixo). Ele envia o payload criado anteriormente e aguarda uma resposta.

👉 Este é o ponto mais crítico do iFlow — onde é importante usar o modo Trace para inspecionar a requisição e a resposta, validando o que foi enviado e recebido.

🔹 5. “OData” (Receiver Channel)

É o endpoint configurado no Adapter OData. Ele define:

 

  • A URL do serviço 
  • O método (GET, POST, PATCH, DELETE)
  • As credenciais de autenticação
  • Eventuais parâmetros adicionais

 

Aqui é onde o iFlow realmente “fala” com o sistema SAP ou outro sistema OData.

🔹 6. “XML to JSON Converter 1”

Converte a resposta do OData (que normalmente vem em XML) para JSON, formato mais fácil de manipular em scripts ou para enviar a outras APIs.

🔹 7. “SET JSON” (Content Modifier)

Aqui o iFlow provavelmente ajusta o JSON resultante — adicionando campos, renomeando chaves ou preparando o payload final para o próximo passo. Pode ser usado para garantir consistência de estrutura antes de enviar ao destino final.

🔹 8. “Groovy Script 1”

Etapa de tratamento customizado. Aqui é possível:

 

  • Fazer validações de negócio
  • Extrair campos específicos do JSON
  • Montar logs
  • Fazer cálculos ou formatações adicionais

 

Um exemplo comum seria:

def body = message.getBody(String)
def json = new groovy.json.JsonSlurper().parseText(body)
json.totalClientes = json.value.size()
message.setBody(new groovy.json.JsonBuilder(json).toPrettyString())
return message

🔹 9. “End 1”

Finaliza o fluxo. Pode apenas encerrar o processo ou enviar os dados tratados para outro sistema (ex: API REST, fila, e-mail, etc.).

entry.title: Re: S/4HANA to Bank SFTP via CPI – AL11 vs Client SFTP
entry.content:
Which approach is SAP-recommended / best practice?

  • Approach 1 beacuse, this will be placed the file into mounted server.  Instead of looking , how CPI pick the file, Check the best approach to place the file from SAP S4.  AL11 is simply a transaction to view application server directories that are defined in the SAP system.

Does SAP provides any free SFTP server for such use?

  • Technically NO. 

If we mount external client SFTP to AL11, does it makes any sense as eventually we will be picking the file from SFTP server.  

  • AL11 folders physically reside on the SAP application server’s filesystem. You can not directly access this either create some program in SAP S4 to call CPI endpoint and push the content to CPI. To access the directories , mount SFTP and access directories.

entry.title: Hire Faster, Smarter in SAP SuccessFactors with LinkedIn RSC
entry.content:
What is LinkedIn Recruiter System Connect (RSC)?

LinkedIn RSC is a integration between LinkedIn Recruiter and SAP SuccessFactors Recruiting. It keeps key hiring data - Candidates, Applications, and Job Requisitions - in sync so recruiters don’t have to copy-paste or jump between tools. With RSC, recruiters can export a LinkedIn profile to SuccessFactors in a click, see LinkedIn profile inside SuccessFactors. This reduces manual work, keeps data consistent, speeds decisions, and boosts recruiter productivity.

Important notes before you enable LinkedIn RSC

  • When data is synced from SAP SuccessFactors Recruiting to LinkedIn, it is stored in LinkedIn-owned data centers in the United States and processed with security controls.
  • LinkedIn processes syncs from any SAP SuccessFactors environment as live updates. To avoid unintended changes, sync only from your Production environment. If you accidentally synced test data to LinkedIn’s live system, contact LinkedIn Support to request deletion of that test data.
  • The sync from SuccessFactors to LinkedIn includes Job Requisitions, Job Applications, and Candidates. The Historical Sync covers the last two years of data (counted from today). Ongoing changes are sent automatically via delta updates after that.
  • The customer are responsible for enabling and maintaining the integration and ensuring compliance with local privacy laws and policies (including DPCS and any regional requirements).

 

Three Step Enablement Process

Watch the full 3 step enablement walkthrough video

 

Step 1: Grant Permissions

  • MDF object permissions for LinkedInDeveloperApplication and LinkedInIntegrationConfiguration.
  • Admin permission: Manage LinkedIn Setup and Implementation.
 

 

Step 2: Set Up LinkedIn Integration and Select Contract

In Security Center, sign in with your LinkedIn account, then choose the correct contract for the tenant.

 

Step 3: Review Field Mapping and Start Sync

Open the LinkedIn Recruiter System Connect Sync Configuration tool. Click View Information button and read the instructions fully. Once you had read the instruction, kindly review/update the field mappings as required. When finalized, go to Data Sync & Monitoring tab and click Initiate Sync.

Points to note

  • General Settings: These cannot be changed after the first data sync starts.
  • Initiate Sync: Triggers a full historical sync (last two years). The can be used once every 24 hours; the button stays disabled until the window resets. This should only be used for full data syncs. Delta syncs run automatically every 30 minutes for new/updated records, so you don’t need full syncs for routine updates.
 

Data flow from LinkedIn to SAP SuccessFactors (One Click Export)

One-Click Export lets recruiters send a candidate from LinkedIn Recruiter directly to a job requisition in SAP SuccessFactors. This is the LinkedIn to SuccessFactors data sync. Candidates exported this way appear in the Applicant Workbench with Forwarded status.

 
Watch: One Click Export
 

Note - You can view the LinkedIn profile inside SuccessFactors only if the user has a valid LinkedIn Recruiter seat that has been synced (seat info refreshes every 24 hours). If the candidate has not accepted DPCS in SuccessFactors, the profile will not link.

 
 
More Resources:
LinkedIn RSC Frequently Asked Questions
LinkedIn RSC Field Mapping Information

entry.title: Re: Tax payable posting to vendor account
entry.content:
Hello @Linhv 

Thank you for contacting SAP Support and submitting your request and your feedback

In SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, posting keys come by default and cannot be modified. In Public Cloud, posting keys are chosen automatically in the background; there is no SSCUI or FBKP-style customisation available. SAP Support Portal-KBA 3419494 - Change posting keys in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

Supported alternatives you might want to consider: Review and utilise the permitted configuration activities, such as document types, automatic account determination, and other SSCUIs, to achieve the business outcome without changing posting keys. If an SSCUI appears to be missing, verify scoping authorisation or whether it exists for your country/version. SAP Support Portal-3419494 - Change posting keys in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

Consult your implementation partner for alternatives. Public Cloud adheres to a fit-to-standard model and limits low-level FI customising, such as posting keys. SAP Zero to Hero

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Sourcing and Procurement
entry.content:
Hello @Veeru582 

What might have happened

In OPD Purchase Order rules, one of the decision tables, such as Channel or Dispatch Time, may contain a column definition that is incorrect or corrupted, such as a manually added Channel/system attribute with an incompatible data type. This inconsistency leads to the WL074 dump at GR. SAP has documented this issue and associates it with the content of the OPD table.

Check SAP KBA 3572781 – Application error: conversion of type “ELEMENT_TEXT” to type “DEEP_STRUC” (WL074) — root cause in Output Parameter Determination decision tables; includes the relevant objects (Channel/Dispatch Time) and components SAP Support Portal-3572781 - Application error: OBJECTS_MOVE_NOT_SUPPORTED, conversion of type "ELEMENT_TEXT" to type "DEEP_STRUCTURE" not supported.

Let me know if it works

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: The amount of activity type is not correct and how to...
entry.content:
Hello @garyding 

Thank you for your follow-up.

Allocation Structure is located in Finance/Controlling, not in EPPM. Refer to SAP Help “Allocation Structures” For more details.  SAP Help Portal-Allocation Structures

The CO configuration activity (SSCUI/Config Activity 104073 – Maintain Allocation Structures) can be used for this configuration. SAP KBA also references the use of activity 104073.SAP Support Portal-3363594 - Error KD503 "Complete allocation structure &" happens during settlement - SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

EPPM projects consume CO settlement settings (project settlement uses allocation/source structures and profiles from Finance). See Help on EPPM/Projects and the 1NT scope coverage. SAP Help Portal-Overhead Accounting-Projects

Why is it not under EPPM in CBC? In SAP Central Business Configuration, detailed config activities appear in the Product-Specific Configuration phase and launch in the S/4HANA Cloud system; organisation is by LoB (Finance), not by EPPM. SAP Learning-Introducing SAP Central Business Configuration

If you still do not see 104073 in CBC, double-check your project is in Product-Specific Configuration and that your CBC role lets you launch config activities.

Let me know if you need further information

With best regards

Chuma
